fierce battles", "body": "Moscow -- Russia said on Wednesday it was fighting intense battles against Ukrainian forces that had penetrated its southern border near a major natural gas transmission hub in one of the largest incursions into Russian territory since the war began.\n\nRussia has advanced this year after the failure of Ukraine's 2023 counteroffensive to achieve any major gains, and has taken 420km of territory from Ukrainian forces since June 14, Russian officials say.\n\nUkraine struck back on Tuesday, and battles continued through the night into Wednesday as Ukrainian forces pushed to the northwest of the border town of Sudzha, 530km southwest of Moscow, Russia's defence ministry said.\n\n\"The Kyiv regime has launched another major provocation,\" President Vladimir Putin {"uri": "8266670255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "09:07:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T09:07:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T09:06:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/aug/09/repelling-ukrainian-push-for-third-day-russia-says/", "title": "Repelling Ukrainian push for third day, Russia says", "body": "KYIV, Ukraine -- Russian troops are battling to push back Ukrainian forces from the Kursk region on the third day of one of the largest cross-border incursions of the war, the Russian Defense Ministry said Thursday.\n\nA ministry statement said the Russian military and border guards have blocked Ukrainian forces from pushing deeper into the region in southwestern Russia. It added that the army is attacking Ukrainian fighters trying to advance into the area from Ukraine's Sumy region.\n\n\"Attempts by individual units to break through deep into the territory in the Kursk direction are being suppressed,\" the ministry said.\n\nUkrainian troops had advanced as much as 9 miles into Russian territory, according to the Institute for the Study of War, a Washington-based think tank.\n\nThe data hasn't been officially confirmed.\n\nKyiv has not commented on the incursion. In a video address to the nation late Thursday, Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy did not mention the fighting in the Kursk region but emphasized that \"Russia brought the war to our land, and it should feel what it has done.\n\n\"Ukrainians know how to achieve their goals,\" Zelenskyy said, adding that he received three \"productive reports, exactly the kind our country needs now\" on Thursday from the commander of Ukraine's armed forces, Oleksandr Syrskyi.\n\nRussia says the military has stemmed Ukrainian advances in the border area about 320 miles southwest of Moscow, but military bloggers and open source data indicate Ukrainian troops have made gains in several areas in Kursk.\n\nThe Kursk region's acting governor, Alexei Smirnov, briefed Russian President Vladimir Putin on conditions there by video link Thursday. Smirnov said the region plans to equip gas stations with electronic warfare units and to provide them with unspecified armored defense.\n\nKursk regional authorities reported Wednesday that at least five civilians, including two ambulance workers, were killed. Russia's Health Ministry said 66 civilians, including nine children, have been wounded in the Kursk region in the three days of fighting.\n\nPutin, who described the incursion as a \"large-scale provocation\" that involved \"indiscriminate shelling of civilian buildings, residential houses and ambulances,\" was briefed on the situation by his top military and security officials on Wednesday.\n\nGen. Valery Gerasimov, the chief of the Russian military's General Staff, told Putin via video link that about 100 Ukrainian soldiers had been killed in the battle and more than 200 others were wounded.\n\nIt wasn't possible to independently verify the Russian claims. During the war, now in its third year, disinformation and propaganda have played a central role.\n\nWhatever the next step by Ukrainian forces, the attack appeared to push the limits on attacking inside Russia with American-provided equipment and put the Russians in disarray. American-made armored vehicles were also filmed being blown up in a Russian counterattack.\n\nThe goal was to shift the fighting -- and Russian soldiers and weaponry -- onto Russian territory and ease the pressure of Moscow's offensive in eastern Ukraine, a senior Ukrainian official said. He asked not to be cited by name, as Ukraine has not acknowledged its soldiers are fighting in Russia.\n\n\"We are at war,\" he said of striking inside enemy territory. \"Why Russia can and we cannot?\"\n\nSo far the assault has played out \"much more successfully\" than previous cross-border raids, the senior Ukrainian official said.\n\nOperating surreptitiously to evade Russian reconnaissance and spies, Ukraine gathered a force that Russia's top general has estimated at 1,000 soldiers for a mechanized assault on Russia's border, an audacious move after repeated setbacks over the past year and a half.\n\nSome analysts estimate that Ukraine has sent hundreds of troops into Russia, a major commitment as its forces are under pressure in the east. Gerasimov said in televised remarks that Ukraine deployed 1,000 soldiers.\n\nIn a statement Thursday, Russia's Ministry of Defense said it was destroying Ukrainian formations and repelling the attack.\n\nBut a prominent Russian military blogger who writes under the name of Rybar said Thursday that Ukrainian forces had Sudzha, the main town in the area, \"practically under full control.\" Videos from Sudzha, verified by The New York Times, show cars trying to leave amid sounds of gunshots and roads littered with burned vehicles and what appeared to be mines.\n\nJohn Kirby, the White House's national security spokesman, declined to comment on the operation and said the Biden administration has reached out to the Ukrainians to better understand the situation.\n\nA State Department spokesperson, Matthew Miller, said Wednesday that the use of U.S.-supplied weapons and munitions in the attack by Ukraine did not violate U.S. policy.\n\n\"Nothing about our policy has changed, and with the actions that they are taking today, they're not in violation of our policy,\" Miller said.\n\nThe cross-border foray would be among Ukraine's largest since Russia launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nSTRATEGIC DECISIONS\n\nKyiv's aim could be to draw Russian reserves to the area, potentially weakening Moscow's offensive operations in several parts of Ukraine's eastern Donetsk region, where Russian forces have increased attacks and are advancing gradually toward operationally significant gains.\n\nBut it could risk stretching outmanned Ukrainian troops farther along the front line, which is more than 620 miles long.\n\nEven if Russia were to commit reserves to stabilize the new front, given its vast manpower and the relatively small number of Ukrainian forces engaged in the operation, it would likely have little long-term impact. Pulling units from the front line to stabilize the Kursk region would also be time consuming.\n\nHowever, the operation could boost Ukrainian morale at a time when Kyiv's forces are facing relentless Russian attacks, with more expected in the coming weeks.\n\nMyhailo Podolyak, a top adviser to Zelenskyy, said Thursday that border region attacks will cause Russia to \"start to realize that the war is slowly creeping inside of Russian territory.\" He also suggested such an operation would improve Kyiv's hand in the event of negotiations with Moscow.\n\n\"When will it be possible to conduct a negotiation process in the way that we can push them or get something from them? Only when the war is not going on according to their scenarios,\" he said.\n\nAndriy Zagorodnyuk, a former Ukrainian defense minister who still advises the government, said the goal was not to hold the territory long-term, but rather to challenge the Russians, to \"divert their forces, attention and resources,\" and \"show they have no reserves and no resilience capacity.\"\n\nKonrad Muzyka, a military analyst for Rochan Consulting in Poland, writing in Ukraine Conflict Monitor, said Ukraine could benefit if the attack reduced Russian attacks in the Donetsk region of Ukraine and allowed Ukraine to maintain a presence in the Kursk area, and thus improve its negotiating position. But Ukraine would be the loser if its troops were pushed back with high losses, he said.\n\n\"There is no middle ground here,\" Muzyka wrote. \"The operation is daring. Let's see what the next few days bring.\"\n\nMilitary analysts say they are skeptical that Russia, which has a vastly larger army and arsenal of weapons than Ukraine, would be forced to divert forces from the fighting inside Ukraine to defend its border. Russia has reserves of conscript soldiers it is prohibited by its policies from deploying into Ukraine, but could on Russian soil.\n\nSeveral Ukrainian brigades stationed along the border region would not comment, along with Ukraine's Defense Ministry and General Staff.\n\nZelenskyy's administration offered its first commentary on the incursion Thursday in a statement by a senior adviser that did not acknowledge any Ukrainian role but portrayed Russians as collectively backing Putin's invasion, signaling the intention was not to affect morale inside Russia.\n\nThe adviser, Mykhailo Podolyak, said Russians were not going to \"come out with flowers to greet the anti-Putin tanks,\" and noted that a million Russians had volunteered to serve in the country's military.\n\nThe Ukrainian push involves regular army units, analysts have noted, in a change from the previous incursions, which were carried out by armed groups of Russian exiles backed by Ukraine's army. That tactic offered Ukraine a veneer of noninvolvement.\n\nEuropean Union spokesperson Peter Stano told the Ukrainian news outlet Suspilne that Ukraine \"has the legal right to defend itself, including by striking at the aggressor on its territory.\"\n\nRussian forces have swiftly repelled previous cross-border incursions, but not before they caused damage and embarrassed authorities.\n\nResponsibility for previous incursions into Russia's Belgorod and Bryansk regions has been claimed by two murky groups: the Russian Volunteer Corps and the Freedom of Russia Legion, made up of Russian citizens who have fought alongside Ukrainian forces.\n\nThe Kursk region's border with Ukraine is 150 miles long, making it possible for saboteur groups to launch swift incursions and capture some ground before Russia deploys reinforcements.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by staff writers of The Associated Press and by Andrew E. Kramer of The New York Times.", "source": {"uri": "arkansasonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ArkansasOnline"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": presses on with offensive, hits Russian airbase", "body": "Map showing the border region between Russia and Ukraine where Ukrainian troops launched an attack on August 6 into Russian territory\n\nUkraine pressed on with a major cross-border incursion into Russia on Friday, also launching a significant air attack on a Russian airfield hundreds of kilometres behind the front lines.\n\nThe Ukrainian offensive into Russia's western Kursk region, launched Tuesday, appears to be the most significant attack on Russian soil since Moscow invaded in February 2022.\n\nRussia says around 1,000 Ukrainian troops and more than two dozen armoured vehicles and tanks were involved in the initial attack, though it has since claimed to have destroyed many more pieces of hardware.\n\nKyiv has not officially taken responsibility for the operation, but Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said in his evening address on Thursday that Russia needed to \"feel\" the consequences of its invasion.\n\nUkraine said Friday it had carried out a massive air strike on a Russian military base in the Lipetsk region, around 280 kilometres (175 miles) from the Russia-Ukraine border.\n\nThe local Russian governor Igor Artamonov reported a \"massive\" drone attack overnight and Russian state news agencies said the airfield was on fire.\n\n\"Last night, the Ukrainian Defence Forces attacked the Lipetsk airfield,\" Ukraine's General Staff said in a post on Telegram.\n\nIt said it had struck \"warehouses containing guided aerial bombs and a number of other facilities\" and that a \"massive fire broke out\" with \"multiple detonations.\"\n\nArtamonov cancelled several public events in the region and issued evacuation orders for districts close to the air base.\n\n- 'Russia brought the war' -\n\nRussia's defence ministry said it destroyed 75 Ukrainian drones overnight, including 19 over the Lipetsk region and seven over Kursk, where Ukraine's four-day incursion has focused.\n\nSeveral nautical drones headed for the annexed peninsula of Crimea were also destroyed, it said.\n\nUkraine's surprise offensive into the Kursk region has appeared to catch Russia off guard, and triggered harsh criticism of the defence ministry by influential military bloggers.\n\nSenior Kyiv officials have stayed tight-lipped over the incursion, though some, including Zelensky have appeared to justify the attack.\n\n\"Russia brought the war to our land and should feel what it has done,\" Zelensky said on Thursday, without directly referring to the offensive.\n\n\"Everyone can see that the Ukraine army knows how to surprise, and knows how to achieve results,\" he said in another apparent reference to the incursion without explicitly mentioning it.\n\nMoscow has also not presented detailed information on the extent of the Ukrainian incursion.\n\nBut the independent US-based Institute for the Study of War said Ukraine had made significant territorial advances.\n\n\"Geolocated footage and Russian claims indicate that Ukrainian forces continued rapid advances further into Kursk Oblast on August 8 (Thursday), and Ukrainian forces are reportedly present in areas as far as 35 kilometers from the international border with Sumy Oblast\" in Ukraine, the institute said in its daily campaign assessment.\n\nIt cautioned, however, that Ukrainian forces \"most certainly do not control\" all of that territory.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said Thursday that its troops were \"continuing to destroy\" armed Ukrainian units and were using air strikes, rocket and artillery fire to try to push them back.\n\nIt said it had rushed in reserves and was \"thwarting attempts to break through\" deeper into the Kursk region.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin has called the incursion a \"large-scale provocation\" by Kyiv, and Russia's top general vowed to crush it.\n\nIn a meeting with the local governor on Thursday, Putin said he needed to show \"courage\" and that Moscow was marshalling all state resources to deal with the situation.\n\nThe health ministry said 66 civilians were wounded, including nine children, in the first three days of the Ukrainian incursion.\n\nOn the first day of the assault, Kursk regional governor Alexei Smirnov said five civilians were killed.\n\nThousands have been evacuated from the region, with Russia putting on an extra train from the regional capital of Kursk to Moscow for those looking to leave.\n\nUkraine has also evacuated several thousand from the Sumy region, which sits across the border from Kursk.\n\nTwo people were killed there over the last 24 hours, Ukraine's interior ministry said Friday.\n\nThe US State Department and European Union have expressed support for Kyiv's right to The data that has not been officially confirmed.\n\nKyiv has not commented on the incursion. border where we have told them they can use US-provided weapons to defend themselves against Russian attacks,\" the official noted.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said on Thursday that the army and the said.\n\nSome Russian bloggers said Ukraine's forces were pushing towards the Kursk nuclear power station, which lies about 60 km (37 miles) northeast of Sudzha.\n\nYuri Podolyaka, a popular {"uri": "2024-08-448736031", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "02:45:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T02:45:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T02:40:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20240809-russia-must-feel-the-war-zelensky-says-as-fighting-continues-on-russian-territory", "title": "Russia must 'feel' the war, Zelensky says as fighting continues on Russian territory", "body": "Three days after it supposedly carried out a surprise raid into Russia's southwestern Kursk region, Ukraine has gradually made its way inland, forcing Russia to call on reserves and evacuated affected areas. Though he hasn't overtly claimed the maneuver, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky explained his country's most deliberate attempt to bring the war to Russia as a way to make Russia \"feel what it has done\" to Ukraine by initiating the war.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Thursday that Russia needed to \"feel\" the consequences of its war as a major Ukrainian incursion across the Russian border stretched into a third day.\n\nPro-Kyiv forces stormed into Russia's southwestern Kursk region on Tuesday morning, deploying around 1,000 troops and more than two dozen armoured vehicles and tanks, according to the Russian army.\n\nIt appears to be the most significant Ukrainian attack into Russia since the war began, with independent analysts suggesting Kyiv's troops had advanced up to 10 kilometres into Russia.\n\n\"Russia brought the war to our land and should feel what it has done,\" Zelensky said in his evening address, without directly referring to the offensive.\n\n\"Ukrainians know how to achieve their goals. And we did not choose to achieve our goals in the war,\" he added.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said Thursday its troops were \"continuing to destroy\" armed Ukrainian units and were using air strikes, rocket and artillery fire to try to push them back.\n\nIt said it had rushed in reserves and was \"thwarting attempts to break through\" deeper into the Kursk region.\n\nThe independent US-based Institute for the Study of War said Ukraine had made significant territorial gains in the first two days of the incursion.\n\n\"Ukrainian forces have made confirmed advances up to 10 kilometres (six miles) into Russia's Kursk Oblast amid continued mechanised offensive operations on Russian territory,\" it said in its latest update.\n\n\"The current confirmed extent and location of Ukrainian advances in Kursk Oblast indicate that Ukrainian forces have penetrated at least two Russian defensive lines and a stronghold,\" it added.\n\n'Entrenching'\n\nKyiv has not officially taken responsibility for the operation, but an aide to Zelensky said Moscow was to blame for the incursion.\n\n\"The root cause of any escalation, shelling, military actions, forced evacuations and destruction of normal life forms -- including within the Russian Federation's own territories like Kursk and Belgorod regions -- is solely Russia's unequivocal aggression,\" presidential aide Mykhailo Podolyak said Thursday on social media.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin has called it a \"large-scale provocation\" by Kyiv and Russia's top general vowed on Wednesday to crush the incursion.\n\nThe US State Department expressed support for Kyiv without directly commenting on the operation.\n\nThe surprise attack appeared to catch Russia's army off guard, triggering criticism of its top brass by the country's influential military bloggers.\n\nThe Ukrainian advance has centred on the logistical hub of Sudzha, a town of around 5,000 inhabitants located eight kilometres from the Ukrainian border.\n\nRussian military bloggers, who have links to the army, also reported Thursday that Kyiv had made significant advances.\n\n\"The situation is complicated and continues to worsen,\" blogger Yury Podolyaka said in a post on Telegram.\n\n\"Sudzha has been completely lost,\" he said.\n\nResidents evacuated from Sudzha also reported a difficult situation, according to images shared by Russia's LDPR party.\n\n\"The situation is bad. There's no communication\" with those who stayed behind, said Alexei, an ambulance worker waiting to receive humanitarian aid.\n\nAnother man also called Alexei, a volunteer, said the evacuees \"feel abandoned\".\n\nThe Dva Mayora Telegram channel said Ukraine was \"entrenching, indicating that the fighting is likely to be long-term\".\n\nThousands evacuated\n\nMany reported Ukrainian troops had advanced towards the town of Korenevo, more than 25 kilometres from the Ukrainian border.\n\nAFP could not verify those reports.\n\nRussian energy giant Gazprom said on Thursday it would continue shipping gas through the Sudzha metering station, the last transit point for Russian gas heading to Europe via Ukraine.\n\nMoscow also said its forces had destroyed a US-made Bradley Fighting Vehicle that Ukraine was using in the incursion.\n\nThe Russian defence ministry had initially blamed a pro-Ukrainian \"sabotage group\" for the raid, but it has since said Ukraine's army is carrying it out.\n\nPro-Kyiv militia, including those made up of Russian citizens fighting against Moscow, have previously staged several cross-border raids.\n\nBut the latest incursion into the Kursk region appears to be the most successful and organised attempt by Ukraine to penetrate Russian territory.\n\nKyiv's objectives remain unclear, with some analysts suggesting it is an attempt to stretch Russia's army, forcing them to move units away from the eastern Donetsk region where they have been advancing.\n\nThe governor of Kursk declared a state of emergency in the region on Wednesday evening, a move that gives authorities the power to restrict movement in a bid to bring the situation under control.\n\nSeveral thousand people have been evacuated on both sides of the border.", Regional officials said that meant restricting access to specific areas.\n\nRussia's health ministry said 31 civilians, including six children, had been wounded. Smirnov said on Tuesday that five people had been killed.\n\nNo information on military casualties was available.\n\nRussia's National Guard said it had beefed up security around the nearby Kursk nuclear power station and its four reactors.\n\nRussia has advanced this year after the failure of Ukraine's 2023 counteroffensive to achieve major gains, and has taken 420 square km (162 square miles) of territory from Ukrainian forces since June 14, Russian officials say.\n\nUkraine struck back on Tuesday, and battles continued through the night into Wednesday as Ukrainian forces pushed to the northwest of the border town of Sudzha, 530 km (330 miles) southwest of Moscow, Russia's defence ministry said.\n\n\"The Kyiv regime has launched another major provocation,\" President Vladimir {"uri": "8266373003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "05:21:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T05:21:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T05:20:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.euractiv.com/section/global-europe/news/russia-battles-ukrainian-troops-for-third-day-after-shock-incursion/", "title": "Russia battles Ukrainian troops for third day after shock incursion", "body": "Russian forces were battling Ukrainian troops for a third day on Thursday (8 August) after they smashed through the Russian border in the Kursk region, an audacious attack on the world's biggest nuclear power that has forced Moscow to call in reserves.\n\nIn one of the biggest Ukrainian attacks on Russia since the war began in February 2022, around 1,000 Ukrainian troops rammed through the Russian border in the early hours of 6 August with tanks and armoured vehicles, covered in the air by swarms of drones and pounding artillery, according to Russian officials.\n\nHeavy fighting was reported near the town of Sudzha, where Russian natural gas flows into Ukraine, raising concerns about a possible sudden stop to transit flows to Europe.\n\nThe incursion has come as a shock to Russia, nearly 2-1/2 years after President Vladimir Putin sent his army into Ukraine.\n\nPutin has cast the Ukrainian offensive as a \"major provocation\". Sergei Mironov, the leader of a Kremlin-loyal political party, called it a \"terrorist attack\" and \"the invasion of an internationally recognised foreign territory\".\n\nKursk's regional acting governor, Alexei Smirnov, said thousands of residents had been evacuated.\n\nThe White House said the United States - Ukraine's biggest backer - had no prior knowledge of the attack.\n\nPentagon spokesperson Sabrina Singh said Ukraine's move on the Kursk region was consistent with US policy.\n\n\"They are taking actions to protect themselves from attacks that are coming from a region that are within the US policy of where they can operate, our weapons, our systems, our capabilities,\" Singh told reporters.\n\nShe said Ukraine's move was not escalatory because \"Ukraine is doing what it needs to do to be successful on the battlefield.\"\n\nRussia's defence ministry said on Thursday that the army and the Federal Security Service (FSB) had halted Ukraine's advance and were battling Kyiv's units in the Kursk region.\n\n\"Units of the Northern group of forces, together with the FSB of Russia, continue to destroy armed formations of the Armed Forces of Ukraine in the Sudzhensky and Korenevsky districts of the Kursk region, directly adjacent to the Russian-Ukrainian border,\" the ministry said.\n\nThe Ukrainian military has remained silent on the Kursk offensive, though President Volodymyr Zelenskyy praised the Ukrainian army on Thursday for its ability \"to surprise\" and achieve results. He did not explicitly reference Kursk.\n\nSome Russian bloggers said Ukraine's forces were pushing towards the Kursk nuclear power station, which lies about 60 km northeast of Sudzha.\n\nYuri Podolyaka, a popular Ukrainian-born, pro-Russian military blogger, said that there were intense battles about 30 km from the Soviet-era nuclear plant, which supplies a large swathe of southern Russia with power.\n\nUkraine's energy minister said gas transit via Sudzha was functioning, despite reports of hostilities there. Most EU nations have reduced dependence on Russian gas, but Austria still receives most of its gas via Ukraine.\n\nThe Center for Information Resilience (CIR), a non-profit open-source analysis organisation, said it was unable to visually confirm any damage to the gas metering station as a result of the incursion, but had verified significant damage to the border checkpoint about 500 metres to the south.\n\n\"This, combined with footage verified by CIR of several Russian soldiers surrendering to Ukrainian soldiers near the entrance of the gas metering plant, makes it likely that the plant has been affected by the Ukrainian incursion, however, the level of damage cannot be verified at this time,\" it said.\n\nThe battles come at a crucial juncture in the conflict, the biggest land war in Europe since World War Two. Kyiv is concerned that US support could weaken if Republican Donald Trump wins the November presidential election.\n\nTrump has said he would end the war, and both Russia and Ukraine are keen to gain the strongest possible bargaining position on the battlefield.\n\nUkraine wants to pin down Russian forces, which control 18% of its territory, though the strategic significance of the border offensive was not immediately clear.\n\nFormer Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said the Ukrainian attack was an attempt to force Moscow to divert resources from the front and to show the West that Ukraine could still fight.\n\nAs a result of the Kursk attack, Medvedev said, Russia should expand its war aims to include taking all of Ukraine.", "source": {"uri": "euractiv.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8266394876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "05:41:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T05:41:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T05:40:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.kyivpost.com/post/37111", "title": "Zelensky Says Russia Must Feel the War as Ukraine Presses Attack", "body": "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Thursday that Russia needed to \"feel\" the consequences of its war as a major Ukrainian incursion across the Russian border stretched into a third day.\n\nPro-Kyiv forces stormed into Russia's southwestern Kursk region on Tuesday morning, deploying around 1,000 troops and more than two dozen armoured vehicles and tanks, according to the Russian army.\n\nIt appears to be the most significant Ukrainian attack into Russia since the war began, with independent analysts suggesting Kyiv's troops had advanced up to 10 kilometres into Russia.\n\n\"Russia brought the war to our land and should feel what it has done,\" Zelensky said in his evening address, without directly referring to the offensive.\n\n\"Ukrainians know how to achieve their goals. And we did not choose to achieve our goals in the war,\" he added.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said Thursday its troops were \"continuing to destroy\" armed Ukrainian units and were using air strikes, rocket and artillery fire to try to push them back.\n\nIt said it had rushed in reserves and was \"thwarting attempts to break through\" deeper into the Kursk region.\n\nThe independent US-based Institute for the Study of War said Ukraine had made significant territorial gains in the first two days of the incursion.\n\n\"Ukrainian forces have made confirmed advances up to 10 kilometres (six miles) into Russia's Kursk Oblast amid continued mechanised offensive operations on Russian territory,\" it said in its latest update.\n\n\"The current confirmed extent and location of Ukrainian advances in Kursk Oblast indicate that Ukrainian forces have penetrated at least two Russian defensive lines and a stronghold,\" it added.\n\n- 'Entrenching' -\n\nKyiv has not officially taken responsibility for the operation, but an aide to Zelensky said Moscow was to blame for the incursion.\n\n\"The root cause of any escalation, shelling, military actions, forced evacuations and destruction of normal life forms -- including within the Russian Federation's own territories like Kursk and Belgorod regions -- is solely Russia's unequivocal aggression,\" presidential aide Mykhailo Podolyak said Thursday on social media.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin has called it a \"large-scale provocation\" by Kyiv and Russia's top general vowed on Wednesday to crush the incursion.\n\nThe US State Department expressed support for Kyiv without directly commenting on the operation.\n\nThe surprise attack appeared to catch Russia's army off guard, triggering criticism of its top brass by the country's influential military bloggers.\n\nThe Ukrainian advance has centred on the logistical hub of Sudzha, a town of around 5,000 inhabitants located eight kilometres from the Ukrainian border.\n\nRussian military bloggers, who have links to the army, also reported Thursday that Kyiv had made significant advances.\n\n\"The situation is complicated and continues to worsen,\" blogger Yury Podolyaka said in a post on Telegram.\n\n\"Sudzha has been completely lost,\" he said.\n\nResidents evacuated from Sudzha also reported a difficult situation, according to images shared by Russia's LDPR party.\n\n\"The situation is bad. There's no communication\" with those who stayed behind, said Alexei, an ambulance worker waiting to receive humanitarian aid.\n\nAnother man also called Alexei, a volunteer, said the evacuees \"feel abandoned\".\n\nThe Dva Mayora Telegram channel said Ukraine was \"entrenching, indicating that the fighting is likely to be long-term\".\n\n- Thousands evacuated -\n\nMany reported Ukrainian troops had advanced towards the town of Korenevo, more than 25 kilometres from the Ukrainian border.\n\nAFP could not verify those reports.\n\nRussian energy giant Gazprom said on Thursday it would continue shipping gas through the Sudzha metering station, the last transit point for Russian gas heading to Europe via Ukraine.\n\nMoscow also said its forces had destroyed a US-made Bradley Fighting Vehicle that Ukraine was using in the incursion.\n\nThe Russian defence ministry had initially blamed a pro-Ukrainian \"sabotage group\" for the raid, but it has since said Ukraine's army is carrying it out.\n\nPro-Kyiv militia, including those made up of Russian citizens fighting against Moscow, have previously staged several cross-border raids.\n\nBut the latest incursion into the Kursk region appears to be the most successful and organised attempt by Ukraine to penetrate Russian territory.\n\nKyiv's objectives remain unclear, with some analysts suggesting it is an attempt to stretch Russia's army, forcing them to move units away from the eastern Donetsk region where they have been advancing.\n\nThe governor of Kursk declared a state of emergency in the region on Wednesday evening, a move that gives authorities the power to restrict movement in a bid to bring the situation under control.\n\nSeveral thousand people have been evacuated on both sides of the border.", {"uri": "8266231204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "02:55:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T02:55:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T02:53:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/world/russia-battles-ukrainian-troops-for-third-day-after-shock-incursion-calls-in-reserves-2649718", "title": "Russia battles Ukrainian troops for third day after shock incursion, calls in reserves", "body": "Moscow: Russian forces were battling Ukrainian troops for a third day on Thursday after they smashed through the Russian border in the Kursk region, an audacious attack on the world's biggest nuclear power that has forced Moscow to call in reserves.\n\nIn one of the biggest Ukrainian attacks on Russia since the war began in February 2022, around 1,000 Ukrainian troops rammed through the Russian border in the early hours of Aug. 6 with tanks and armoured vehicles, covered in the air by swarms of drones and pounding artillery, according to Russian officials.\n\nHeavy fighting was reported near the town of Sudzha, where Russian natural gas flows into Ukraine, raising concerns about a possible sudden stop to transit flows to Europe. The incursion has come as a shock to Russia, nearly 2-1/2 years after President Vladimir Putin sent his army into Ukraine.\n\nPutin has cast the Ukrainian offensive as a \"major provocation\". Sergei Mironov, the leader of a Kremlin-loyal political party, called it a \"terrorist attack\" and \"the invasion of an internationally recognised foreign territory\".\n\nKursk's regional acting governor, Alexei Smirnov, said thousands of residents had been evacuated. The White House said the United States - Ukraine's biggest backer - had no prior knowledge of the attack.\n\nPentagon spokesperson Sabrina Singh said Ukraine's move on the Kursk region was consistent with U.S. policy.\n\n\"They are taking actions to protect themselves from attacks that are coming from a region that are within the U.S. policy of where they can operate, our weapons, our systems, our capabilities,\" Singh told reporters.\n\nShe said Ukraine's move was not escalatory because \"Ukraine is doing what it needs to do to be successful on the battlefield.\"\n\nRussia's defence ministry said on Thursday that the army and the Federal Security Service (FSB) had halted Ukraine's advance and were battling Kyiv's units in the Kursk region.\n\n\"Units of the Northern group of forces, together with the FSB of Russia, continue to destroy armed formations of the Armed Forces of Ukraine in the Sudzhensky and Korenevsky districts of the Kursk region, directly adjacent to the Russian-Ukrainian border,\" the ministry said.\n\nThe Ukrainian military has remained silent on the Kursk offensive, though President Volodymyr Zelenskiy praised the Ukrainian army on Thursday for its ability \"to surprise\" and achieve results. He did not explicitly reference Kursk.\n\nSome Russian bloggers said Ukraine's forces were pushing towards the Kursk nuclear power station, which lies about 60 km (37 miles) northeast of Sudzha. Yuri Podolyaka, a popular Ukrainian-born, pro-Russian military blogger, said that there were intense battles about 30 km from the Soviet-era nuclear plant, which supplies a large swathe of southern Russia with power.\n\nUkraine's energy minister said gas transit via Sudzha was functioning, despite reports of hostilities there. Most EU nations have reduced dependence on Russian gas, but Austria still receives most of its gas via Ukraine.\n\nThe Center for Information Resilience (CIR), a non-profit open-source analysis organisation, said it was unable to visually confirm any damage to the gas metering station as a result of the incursion, but had verified significant damage to the border checkpoint about 500 metres (550 yards) to the south.\n\n\"This, combined with footage verified by CIR of several Russian soldiers surrendering to Ukrainian soldiers near the entrance of the gas metering plant, makes it likely that the plant has been affected by the Ukrainian incursion, however, the level of damage cannot be verified at this time,\" it said.\n\nThe battles come at a crucial juncture in the conflict, the biggest land war in Europe since World War Two. Kyiv is concerned that U.S. support could weaken if Republican Donald Trump wins the November presidential election.\n\nTrump has said he would end the war, and both Russia and Ukraine are keen to gain the strongest possible bargaining position on the battlefield.\n\nUkraine wants to pin down Russian forces, which control 18% of its territory, though the strategic significance of the border offensive was not immediately clear.\n\nFormer Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said the Ukrainian attack was an attempt to force Moscow to divert resources from the front and to show the West that Ukraine could still fight.\n\nAs a result of the Kursk attack, Medvedev said, Russia should expand its war aims to include taking all of Ukraine.\n\nHe said Moscow's \"Special Military Operation\" should acquire an \"openly extraterritorial character\", with Russian troops moving on Odesa, Kharkiv, Dnipro, Mykolayiv, Kyiv \"and beyond\".", "source": {"uri": "news9live.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8266452387", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "06:31:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T06:31:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T06:30:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/world/2024-08-09-russia-must-feel-war-consequences-says-zelensky-amid-ukrainian-attack/", "title": "Russia must feel war consequences, says Zelensky amid Ukrainian attack", "body": "Three days into Ukraine's cross-border attack on Russia's Kursk region, Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky has said Moscow must \"feel\" the consequences for its invasion of Ukraine.\n\n\"Russia brought the war to our land and should feel what it has done\", Mr Zelensky said in his Thursday evening address, without directly referencing the Ukrainian offensive.\n\n\"Ukrainians know how to achieve their goals. And we did not choose to achieve our goals in the war,\" he added.\n\nRussia says at least 1,000 Ukrainian troops, supported by tanks and armoured vehicles, entered its territory on Tuesday morning - in what appears to be one of the largest assaults on Russian soil since the war began.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin earlier accused Ukraine of a \"major provocation\".\n\nUkrainian officials have been largely silent on the offensive. The exact situation on the ground is hard to determine, with few specific details released by either side.\n\n\"Everyone can see that the Ukrainian army knows how to surprise [and] achieve results,\" the Ukrainian president said earlier on Thursday, without directly referencing the assault.\n\nThe International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) said it was monitoring Kursk's nuclear plant, according to state-owned Russian news agency RIA-Novosti.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said on Thursday that its troops were \"continuing to destroy\" armed Ukrainian units with air strikes, rockets and artillery fire.\n\nThe ministry said Russian reserves had been rushed to the region.\n\nThe Institute for the Study of War, a well-respected think tank, said geo-located footage showed Ukrainian armoured vehicles had advanced to positions 10km (6.2 miles) into the Kursk region in the first two days of the incursion.\n\nRussia's military leadership is under severe scrutiny domestically, as some popular and generally well-informed pro-war Telegram channels have said the situation on the ground is not as stable as the Kremlin has suggested.\n\nThe influential pro-war Rybar Telegram channel strongly criticised the highest ranks of the Russian military on Wednesday, saying that \"for two months the full information was sent to the useless headquarters\", adding that there was enough time \"to make an appropriate decision\".\n\nIn a publicised video call with Mr Putin on Thursday, Kursk regional governor Alexei Smirnov said buses and trains were being used to evacuate people to other Russian regions that had offered to accommodate them.\n\nThe efforts were being hampered by Ukrainian shelling, he added.\n\nPosts from his Telegram account continued to warn Kursk residents of missile strikes throughout the night and into Friday morning.\n\nThe Russian defence ministry said in a statement on Telegram on Friday morning that it had intercepted and destroyed 75 UAV missiles, which had flown over regions including Kursk.\n\nRussian state news agencies reported early on Friday that a fire had broken out at a military airfield in the neighbouring Lipetsk region. It was not clear what caused the fire or whether it was related to the fighting in Kursk.\n\nA red threat level alert had been issued in Lipetsk, but was later lifted on Friday morning. The regional governor Igor Artamonov earlier said an energy infrastructure facility had been damaged and power supply disruptions reported.\n\nLocal leaders in regions adjacent to Kursk, in both Russia and Ukraine, also told residents to leave for their safety.\n\nOn Wednesday, the head of the Ukrainian region of Sumy, Volodymyr Artyukh, ordered the evacuation of areas bordering Kursk.\n\nIn the Russian region of Belgorod, governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said on Thursday that settlements across his province had been attacked by Ukrainian forces over the past 24 hours.\n\nUkraine's key allies seemed surprised by the offensive - with White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre saying the US was reaching out to Ukraine to better understand what it hoped to achieve.\n\nThis is not the first incursion into Russia by fighters based in Ukraine. Some groups of anti-Kremlin Russians launched raids last year, which were repelled.\n\nThe forces crossed into the Belgorod and Kursk regions again in March, where they engaged in clashes with Russian security forces.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, Ukrainian MP Oleksiy Honcharenko said the Ukrainian army had established control over the Sudzha gas hub, a major facility involved in the transit of natural gas from Russia to the EU via Ukraine, which has continued despite the war.\n\nIt is the only point of entry for Russian gas into the EU.\n\nAs of Thursday, gas was reportedly still flowing from Sudzha.\n\nRussia's National Guard said it had reinforced security around Kursk's nuclear power station, which lies some 70km north-east of Sudzha.\n\nFor the past few months Russia has made incremental gains in eastern Ukraine, as many of Kyiv's ground forces have faced relentless attacks in the eastern Donbas region.\n\nIn a recent interview, Ukraine's head of defence intelligence, Kyrylo Budanov, said the main offensive by Russian forces \"is expected to be over in a month and a half to two months\".", "source": {"uri": "the-star.co.ke", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "2024-08-448994056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "08:29:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T08:29:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T08:27:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/ukraine-presses-offensive-hits-russian-airbase-1850449", "title": "Ukraine Presses On With Offensive, Hits Russian Airbase", "body": "Ukraine pressed on with a major cross-border incursion into Russia on Friday, also launching a significant air attack on a Russian airfield hundreds of kilometres behind the front lines.\n\nThe Ukrainian offensive into Russia's western Kursk region, launched Tuesday, appears to be the most significant attack on Russian soil since Moscow invaded in February 2022.\n\nRussia says around 1,000 Ukrainian troops and more than two dozen armoured vehicles and tanks were involved in the initial attack, though it has since claimed to have destroyed many more pieces of hardware.\n\nKyiv has not officially taken responsibility for the operation, but Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said in his evening address on Thursday that Russia needed to \"feel\" the consequences of its invasion.\n\nUkraine said Friday it had carried out a massive air strike on a Russian military base in the Lipetsk region, around 280 kilometres (175 miles) from the Russia-Ukraine border.\n\nThe local Russian governor Igor Artamonov reported a \"massive\" drone attack overnight and Russian state news agencies said the airfield was on fire.\n\n\"Last night, the Ukrainian Defence Forces attacked the Lipetsk airfield,\" Ukraine's General Staff said in a post on Telegram.\n\nIt said it had struck \"warehouses containing guided aerial bombs and a number of other facilities\" and that a \"massive fire broke out\" with \"multiple detonations.\"\n\nArtamonov cancelled several public events in the region and issued evacuation orders for districts close to the air base.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said it destroyed 75 Ukrainian drones overnight, including 19 over the Lipetsk region and seven over Kursk, where Ukraine's four-day incursion has focused.\n\nSeveral nautical drones headed for the annexed peninsula of Crimea were also destroyed, it said.\n\nUkraine's surprise offensive into the Kursk region has appeared to catch Russia off guard, and triggered harsh criticism of the defence ministry by influential military bloggers.\n\nSenior Kyiv officials have stayed tight-lipped over the incursion, though some, including Zelensky have appeared to justify the attack.\n\n\"Russia brought the war to our land and should feel what it has done,\" Zelensky said on Thursday, without directly referring to the offensive.\n\n\"Everyone can see that the Ukraine army knows how to surprise, and knows how to achieve results,\" he said in another apparent reference to the incursion without explicitly mentioning it.\n\nMoscow has also not presented detailed information on the extent of the Ukrainian incursion.\n\nBut the independent US-based Institute for the Study of War said Ukraine had made significant territorial advances.\n\n\"Geolocated footage and Russian claims indicate that Ukrainian forces continued rapid advances further into Kursk Oblast on August 8 (Thursday), and Ukrainian forces are reportedly present in areas as far as 35 kilometers from the international border with Sumy Oblast\" in Ukraine, the institute said in its daily campaign assessment.\n\nIt cautioned, however, that Ukrainian forces \"most certainly do not control\" all of that territory.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said Thursday that its troops were \"continuing to destroy\" armed Ukrainian units and were using air strikes, rocket and artillery fire to try to push them back.\n\nIt said it had rushed in reserves and was \"thwarting attempts to break through\" deeper into the Kursk region.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin has called the incursion a \"large-scale provocation\" by Kyiv, and Russia's top general vowed to crush it.\n\nIn a meeting with the local governor on Thursday, Putin said he needed to show \"courage\" and that Moscow was marshalling all state resources to deal with the situation.\n\nThe health ministry said 66 civilians were wounded, including nine children, in the first three days of the Ukrainian incursion.\n\nOn the first day of the assault, Kursk regional governor Alexei Smirnov said five civilians were killed.\n\nThousands have been evacuated from the region, with Russia putting on an extra train from the regional capital of Kursk to Moscow for those looking to leave.\n\nUkraine has also evacuated several thousand from the Sumy region, which sits across the border from Kursk.\n\nTwo people were killed there over the last 24 hours, Ukraine's interior ministry said Friday.\n\nThe US State Department and European Union have expressed support for Kyiv's right to defend itself from Russian aggression, without directly commenting on the operation.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times AU"}, "authors": {"uri": "8266014755", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:18:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:18:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:13:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/world/russia-battles-ukrainian-troops-for-third-day-after-shock-incursion1", "title": "Russia battles Ukrainian troops for third day after shock incursion", "body": "Russian forces were battling Ukrainian troops for a third day on Thursday after they smashed through the Russian border in the Kursk region, an audacious attack on the world's biggest nuclear power that has forced Moscow to call in reserves.\n\nIn one of the biggest Ukrainian attacks on Russia of the two-year-old war, around 1,000 Ukrainian troops rammed through the Russian border in the early hours of Aug. 6 with tanks and armoured vehicles, covered in the air by swarms of drones and pounding artillery, according to Russian officials.\n\nHeavy fighting was reported near the town of Sudzha, where Russian natural gas flows into Ukraine, raising concerns about a possible sudden stop to transit flows to Europe.\n\nThe incursion has come as a shock to Russia, nearly two-and-a-half years since President Vladimir Putin sent his army into Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nPutin has cast the Ukrainian offensive as a \"major provocation\". Sergei Mironov, leader of a Kremlin-loyal political party, called it a \"terrorist attack\" and \"the invasion of an internationally recognized foreign territory\".\n\nKursk's regional acting governor, Alexei Smirnov, said that thousands of residents had been evacuated.\n\nThe White House said the United States - Ukraine's biggest backer - had no prior knowledge of the attack. Washington has asked Ukraine for details on their military objectives, said a U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, on Thursday.\n\n\"They are operating within the area north of the border where we have told them they can use U.S.-provided weapons to defend themselves against Russian attacks,\" the official noted.\n\nRussia's defense ministry said on Thursday that the army and the Federal Security Service (FSB) had halted the Ukrainian advance and were battling Ukrainian units in the Kursk region.\n\n\"Units of the Northern group of forces, together with the FSB of Russia, continue to destroy armed formations of the Armed Forces of Ukraine in the Sudzhensky and Korenevsky districts of the Kursk region, directly adjacent to the Russian-Ukrainian border,\" the ministry said.\n\nThe Ukrainian military has remained silent on the Kursk offensive, though President Volodymyr Zelenskiy praised the Ukrainian army on Thursday for its ability \"to surprise\" and achieve results. He did not explicitly reference Kursk.\n\nSome Russian bloggers said Ukraine's forces were pushing towards the Kursk nuclear power station, which lies about 60 km northeast of Sudzha.\n\nYuri Podolyaka, a popular Ukrainian-born, pro-Russian military blogger, said that there were intense battles about 30 km from the Soviet-era nuclear plant, which supplies a large swathe of southern Russia with power.\n\nCRITICAL JUNCTURE\n\nUkraine's energy minister said gas transit via Sudzha was still functioning, despite reports of hostilities there. Most EU nations have reduced their dependence on Russian gas, but Austria is one country that still receives most of its gas via Ukraine.\n\nThe Center for Information Resilience, a non-profit open-source analysis organization, said it was unable to visually confirm any damage to the gas metering station as a result of the incursion, but had verified significant damage to the border checkpoint about 500 metres (550 yards) to the south.\n\n\"This, combined with footage verified by CIR of several Russian soldiers surrendering to Ukrainian soldiers near the entrance of the gas metering plant, makes it likely that the plant has been affected by the Ukrainian incursion, however, the level of damage cannot be verified at this time,\" it said.\n\nThe battles come at a crucial juncture in the conflict, the biggest land war in Europe since World War Two. Kyiv is concerned that U.S. support could weaken if Republican Donald Trump wins the November presidential election.\n\nTrump has said he would end the war, and both Russia and Ukraine are keen to gain the strongest possible bargaining position on the battlefield.\n\nUkraine wants to pin down Russian forces, which control 18% of its territory, though the strategic significance of the border offensive was not immediately clear.\n\nFormer Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said the Ukrainian attack was an attempt to force Russia to divert resources from the front and to show the West that Ukraine could still fight.\n\nAs a result of the Kursk attack, Medvedev said, Russia should expand its war aims to include taking all of Ukraine.\n\n\"From this moment on, the SVO (Special Military Operation) should acquire an openly extraterritorial character,\" Medvedev said, adding that Russian forces should go to Odesa, Kharkiv, Dnipro, Mykolayiv, Kyiv \"and beyond\".\n\n\"We will stop only when we consider it acceptable and profitable for ourselves.\"\n\n\u00a9 Thomson Reuters 2024.", "source": {"uri": "japantoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Japan Today"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-08-448822760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "05:11:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T05:11:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T04:52:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/russia-battles-ukrainian-forces-for-third-day-as-kyiv-launches-unprecedented-cross-border-attack-kursk-region-updates-2024-08-09-945993", "title": "Russia battles Ukrainian forces for third day as Kyiv launches unprecedented cross-border attack", "body": "Moscow: Russian forces continued to battle Ukrainian troops for a third day on Thursday in the southwestern Kursk region after Kyiv launched an unprecedented cross-border incursion, one of the largest in the over two-year war, according to the Russian Defence Ministry. Around 1,000 Ukrainian troops supported by tanks and armoured combat vehicles crossed into Russia on August 6 through the border, taking Russia by surprise.\n\nAs per an official statement from Russia, its military and border guards have blocked Ukrainian forces from pushing deeper into the region in the southwestern part of the country and the Army is attacking Ukrainian fighters trying to advance into the area from Ukraine's Sumy region. \"Attempts by individual units to break through deep into the territory in the Kursk direction are being suppressed,\" the ministry said.\n\nThe attack has not been acknowledged by Ukraine but it would be among its largest assault since Russia's full-scale invasion in February 2022, and unprecedented for its deployment of Ukrainian military units on the front lines in the country's east. Kyiv's aim could be to draw Russian reserves to the area, potentially weakening Moscow's offensive operations in several parts of Ukraine's eastern Donetsk region where Russian forces have increased attacks and are advancing gradually toward operationally significant gains.\n\n100 Ukrainian soldiers killed, Putin decries 'provocation'\n\nRussia says the military has stemmed Ukrainian advances in the border area about 500 kilometres (about 320 miles) southwest of Moscow, but military bloggers and open-source data indicate Ukrainian troops have made gains in several areas in Kursk. The Kursk region's acting governor, Alexei Smirnov, briefed Russian President Vladimir Putin on conditions there by video link on Thursday.\n\nStudy of War, a Washington-based think tank, said Ukrainian troops had advanced as much as 15 kilometres (9 miles) into Russian territory, but the data is yet to be confirmed. In a video address to the nation late Thursday, Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy did not mention the fighting in the Kursk region, but said \"Russia brought the war to our land, and it should feel what it has done.\"\n\nGeneral Valery Gerasimov, the chief of the Russian military's General Staff, told Putin via video link that about 100 Ukrainian soldiers had been killed in the battle and more than 200 others were wounded. at least five civilians, including two ambulance workers, have also been killed in the attack, as per regional authorities.\n\nPutin, who described the incursion as a \"large-scale provocation\" that involved \"indiscriminate shelling of civilian buildings, residential houses and ambulances\" was briefed on the situation by his top military and security officials on Wednesday. He instructed the Cabinet to coordinate assistance to the Kursk region.\n\nUkraine launches 'massive' drone attack\n\nMeanwhile, Russia began evacuating people from parts of its western region of Lipetsk after a massive attack\" by Ukrainian drones caused explosions, disrupted power supply, and wounded six people, regional governor Igor Artamonov said. Four villages were being evacuated after a state of emergency was declared in the Lipetsk municipal district, according to Artamonov.\n\nA fire had broken out at the air base outside the city of Lipetsk, the Interfax news agency reported local emergency officials as saying. Calls on social media to evacuate the entire city were part of a campaign of psychological warfare by Ukraine, accused the regional governor. Ukrainian authorities have not reported any strikes on the Lipetsk region.\n\nRisks for Ukrainian soldiers\n\nThe operation could boost Ukrainian morale at a time when Kyiv's forces are facing relentless Russian attacks and are expected to face more in the coming weeks. However, it could risk stretching outmanned Ukrainian troops further along the front line, which is more than 1,000 kilometres (620 miles) long. Even if Russia were to commit reserves to stabilise the new front, given its vast manpower and the relatively small number of Ukrainian forces engaged in the operation, it would likely have little long-term impact.\n\nRussian forces have swiftly repelled previous cross-border incursions, but not before they caused damage and embarrassed authorities. Smirnov said the region plans to equip gas stations with electronic warfare units and to provide them with unspecified armoured defence.\n\nMeanwhile, the US Defence Department, or Pentagon, said Ukraine's move on the Kursk region was consistent with US policy. \"They are taking actions to protect themselves from attacks that are coming from a region that are within the US policy of where they can operate, our weapons, our systems, our capabilities,\" Pentagon Press Secretary Sabrina Singh told reporters.\n\n(with inputs from agencies)", "source": {"uri": "indiatvnews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8266398013", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "05:44:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T05:44:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T05:43:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/08/09/russias-lipetsk-region-hit-by-massive-drone-attack-ukraines-attack-on-kursk-continues/", "title": "Russia's Lipetsk region hit by 'massive' drone attack, Ukraine's attack on Kursk continues", "body": "Russia evacuated people on Friday from parts of its western region of Lipetsk after a \"massive attack\" by Ukrainian drones caused explosions, disrupted power supply and wounded six people, regional governor Igor Artamonov said.\n\nFour villages, some of them situated near an air force base, were being evacuated after a state of emergency was declared in the Lipetsk municipal district, Artamonov said on the Telegram messaging app.\n\nA fire had broken out at the air base outside Lipetsk city, the Interfax news agency reported, citing local emergency officials.\n\nSeparately, the governor of the Russian-held city of Sevastopol in Crimea, Mikhail Razvozhayev, said on Telegram that Russian forces destroyed three drones and three drone boats near the city.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said a total of 75 Ukrainian drones have been destroyed overnight over Russia, according to the RIA news agency, most of them over the Belgorod and Lipetsk regions.\n\nUkrainian authorities have not reported any strikes on the Lipetsk region.\n\nRussian forces were battling Ukrainian troops for a third day on Thursday after they smashed through the Russian border in the Kursk region, an audacious attack on the world's biggest nuclear power that has forced Moscow to call in reserves.\n\nIn one of the biggest Ukrainian attacks on Russia since the war began in February 2022, around 1,000 Ukrainian troops rammed through the Russian border in the early hours of Aug. 6 with tanks and armoured vehicles, covered in the air by swarms of drones and pounding artillery, according to Russian officials.\n\nHeavy fighting was reported near the town of Sudzha, where Russian natural gas flows into Ukraine, raising concerns about a possible sudden stop to transit flows to Europe.\n\nThe incursion has come as a shock to Russia, nearly 2-1/2 years after President Vladimir Putin sent his army into Ukraine.\n\nPutin has cast the Ukrainian offensive as a \"major provocation\". Sergei Mironov, the leader of a Kremlin-loyal political party, called it a \"terrorist attack\" and \"the invasion of an internationally recognised foreign territory\".\n\nKursk's regional acting governor, Alexei Smirnov, said thousands of residents had been evacuated.\n\nThe White House said the United States - Ukraine's biggest backer - had no prior knowledge of the attack.\n\nPentagon spokesperson Sabrina Singh said Ukraine's move on the Kursk region was consistent with U.S. policy.\n\n\"They are taking actions to protect themselves from attacks that are coming from a region that are within the U.S. policy of where they can operate, our weapons, our systems, our capabilities,\" Singh told reporters.\n\nShe said Ukraine's move was not escalatory because \"Ukraine is doing what it needs to do to be successful on the battlefield.\"\n\nRussia's defence ministry said on Thursday that the army and the Federal Security Service (FSB) had halted Ukraine's advance and were battling Kyiv's units in the Kursk region.\n\n\"Units of the Northern group of forces, together with the FSB of Russia, continue to destroy armed formations of the Armed Forces of Ukraine in the Sudzhensky and Korenevsky districts of the Kursk region, directly adjacent to the Russian-Ukrainian border,\" the ministry said.\n\nThe Ukrainian military has remained silent on the Kursk offensive, though President Volodymyr Zelenskiy praised the Ukrainian army on Thursday for its ability \"to surprise\" and achieve results. He did not explicitly reference Kursk.\n\nSome Russian bloggers said Ukraine's forces were pushing towards the Kursk nuclear power station, which lies about 60 km (37 miles) northeast of Sudzha.\n\nYuri Podolyaka, a popular Ukrainian-born, pro-Russian military blogger, said that there were intense battles about 30 km from the Soviet-era nuclear plant, which supplies a large swathe of southern Russia with power.\n\nCRITICAL JUNCTURE\n\nUkraine's energy minister said gas transit via Sudzha was functioning, despite reports of hostilities there. Most EU nations have reduced dependence on Russian gas, but Austria still receives most of its gas via Ukraine.\n\nThe Center for Information Resilience (CIR), a non-profit open-source analysis organisation, said it was unable to visually confirm any damage to the gas metering station as a result of the incursion, but had verified significant damage to the border checkpoint about 500 metres (550 yards) to the south.\n\n\"This, combined with footage verified by CIR of several Russian soldiers surrendering to Ukrainian soldiers near the entrance of the gas metering plant, makes it likely that the plant has been affected by the Ukrainian incursion, however, the level of damage cannot be verified at this time,\" it said.\n\nThe battles come at a crucial juncture in the conflict, the biggest land war in Europe since World War Two. Kyiv is concerned that U.S. support could weaken if Republican Donald Trump wins the November presidential election.\n\nTrump has said he would end the war, and both Russia and Ukraine are keen to gain the strongest possible bargaining position on the battlefield.\n\nUkraine wants to pin down Russian forces, which control 18% of its territory, though the strategic significance of the border offensive was not immediately clear.\n\nFormer Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said the Ukrainian attack was an attempt to force Moscow to divert resources from the front and to show the West that Ukraine could still fight.\n\nAs a result of the Kursk attack, Medvedev said, Russia should expand its war aims to include taking all of Ukraine.\n\nHe said Moscow's \"Special Military Operation\" should acquire an \"openly extraterritorial character\", with Russian troops moving on Odesa, Kharkiv, Dnipro, Mykolayiv, Kyiv \"and beyond\".", "source": {"uri": "cyprus-mail.com", "dataType": And it was not our choice to achieve war goals,\" he added.\n\nUkrainian officials have remained largely silent on the offensive. The exact situation on the ground is difficult to determine, as both sides have not provided concrete information.\n\n\"Everyone can see that the Ukrainian army knows how to surprise [and] achieve results,\" the Ukrainian president said earlier on Thursday, without directly referring to the offensive.\n\nThe Russian defence ministry said on Thursday that its troops \"continue to destroy\" armed Ukrainian units with air strikes, missiles and artillery fire, while sending Russian reserve forces to the region.\n\nThe Institute for the Study of War has stated that Ukrainian armoured vehicles have advanced in the Kursk region during the first two days of the incursion, taking up positions at a 10km depth.\n\nMeanwhile, Russian military actions are being analysed in the country, with prominent pro-Kremlin Telegram channels such as Rybar criticising top brass for ignoring warnings, saying that \"for two months all information was sent to the useless headquarters\", adding that there was enough time to \"make an appropriate decision\".\n\nKursk Governor Alexei Smirnov said in a video call with President Putin on Thursday that evacuations to other regions of Russia were continuing, although hampered by Ukrainian shelling.\n\nLocal leaders in both Russia and Ukraine have called on people in nearby regions to evacuate for their own safety.\n\nThroughout the night on Friday and into Friday morning, posts on Smirnov's Telegram account\n\nwarned Kursk residents of missile strikes, while the Russian defence ministry claimed on Friday morning that 75 missiles had been intercepted.\n\nRussian state news agencies reported early on Friday morning that a fire had broken out at a military airfield in the neighbouring town of Lipetsk, although the cause was unclear. A red alert was briefly issued in Lipetsk, with the region's governor, Igor Artamonov, saying that an energy facility had been damaged, causing power outages.\n\nThe White House said it had no prior knowledge of a Ukrainian attack on Russia's Kursk region, while Pentagon spokeswoman Sabrina Singh confirmed that the move was in line with US policy.\n\nSingh explained that Ukraine was \"acting to protect itself\" and stressed that the operation was not escalatory because \"Ukraine is doing what it needs to do to succeed on the battlefield\".\n\nAlso read: State of emergency declared in Kursk {"uri": "8266247733", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "03:13:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T03:13:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T03:12:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/zelensky-says-russia-must-feel-the-war-as-ukraine-presses-attack-9007019.html", "title": "Zelensky Says Russia Must Feel The War As Ukraine Presses Attack - News18", "body": "Pro-Kyiv forces stormed into Russia's southwestern Kursk region on Tuesday morning, deploying around 1,000 troops and more than two dozen armoured vehicles.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Thursday that Russia needed to \"feel\" the consequences of its war as a major Ukrainian incursion across the Russian border stretched into a third day.\n\nPro-Kyiv forces stormed into Russia's southwestern Kursk region on Tuesday morning, deploying around 1,000 troops and more than two dozen armoured vehicles and tanks, according to the Russian army.\n\nIt appears to be the most significant Ukrainian attack into Russia since the war began, with independent analysts suggesting Kyiv's troops had advanced up to 10 kilometres into Russia.\n\n\"Russia brought the war to our land and should feel what it has done,\" Zelensky said in his evening address, without directly referring to the offensive.\n\n\"Ukrainians know how to achieve their goals. And we did not choose to achieve our goals in the war,\" he added.\n\nRussia's defence ministry said Thursday its troops were \"continuing to destroy\" armed Ukrainian units and were using air strikes, rocket and artillery fire to try to push them back.\n\nIt said it had rushed in reserves and was \"thwarting attempts to break through\" deeper into the Kursk region.\n\nThe independent US-based Institute for the Study of War said Ukraine had made significant territorial gains in the first two days of the incursion.\n\n\"Ukrainian forces have made confirmed advances up to 10 kilometres (six miles) into Russia's Kursk Oblast amid continued mechanised offensive operations on Russian territory,\" it said in its latest update.\n\n\"The current confirmed extent and location of Ukrainian advances in Kursk Oblast indicate that Ukrainian forces have penetrated at least two Russian defensive lines and a stronghold,\" it added.\n\nKyiv has not officially taken responsibility for the operation, but an aide to Zelensky said Moscow was to blame for the incursion.\n\n\"The root cause of any escalation, shelling, military actions, forced evacuations and destruction of normal life forms -- including within the Russian Federation's own territories like Kursk and Belgorod regions -- is solely Russia's unequivocal aggression,\" presidential aide Mykhailo Podolyak said Thursday on social media.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin has called it a \"large-scale provocation\" by Kyiv and Russia's top general vowed on Wednesday to crush the incursion.\n\nThe US State Department expressed support for Kyiv without directly commenting on the operation.\n\nThe surprise attack appeared to catch Russia's army off guard, triggering criticism of its top brass by the country's influential military bloggers.\n\nThe Ukrainian advance has centred on the logistical hub of Sudzha, a town of around 5,000 inhabitants located eight kilometres from the Ukrainian border.\n\nRussian military bloggers, who have links to the army, also reported Thursday that Kyiv had made significant advances.\n\n\"The situation is complicated and continues to worsen,\" blogger Yury Podolyaka said in a post on Telegram.\n\n\"Sudzha has been completely lost,\" he said.\n\nResidents evacuated from Sudzha also reported a difficult situation, according to images shared by Russia's LDPR party.\n\n\"The situation is bad. There's no communication\" with those who stayed behind, said Alexei, an ambulance worker waiting to receive humanitarian aid.\n\nAnother man also called Alexei, a volunteer, said the evacuees \"feel abandoned\".\n\nThe Dva Mayora Telegram channel said Ukraine was \"entrenching, indicating that the fighting is likely to be long-term\".\n\nMany reported Ukrainian troops had advanced towards the town of Korenevo, more than 25 kilometres from the Ukrainian border.\n\nAFP could not verify those reports.\n\nRussian energy giant Gazprom said on Thursday it would continue shipping gas through the Sudzha metering station, the last transit point for Russian gas heading to Europe via Ukraine.\n\nMoscow also said its forces had destroyed a US-made Bradley Fighting Vehicle that Ukraine was using in the incursion.\n\nThe Russian defence ministry had initially blamed a pro-Ukrainian \"sabotage group\" for the raid, but it has since said Ukraine's army is carrying it out.\n\nPro-Kyiv militia, including those made up of Russian citizens fighting against Moscow, have previously staged several cross-border raids.\n\nBut the latest incursion into the Kursk region appears to be the most successful and organised attempt by Ukraine to penetrate Russian territory.\n\nKyiv's objectives remain unclear, with some analysts suggesting it is an attempt to stretch Russia's army, forcing them to move units away from the eastern Donetsk region where they have been advancing.\n\nThe governor of Kursk declared a state of emergency in the region on Wednesday evening, a move that gives authorities the power to restrict movement in a bid to bring the situation under control.\n\nSeveral thousand people have been evacuated on both sides of the border.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com",
